Award.AwardTitle: Obstructions to positive curvature and symmetry
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Award: DMS 1404670, Principal Investigator: Lee Kennard, Guofang Wei

The curvature of a manifold is an attempt to quantify the ways that a space may bend, beginning with the Euclidean plane, whose flatness is captured by declaring the plane to have zero curvature. The two-dimensional round sphere in three-dimensional space has positive curvature, of a size that reflects the sense that as one traverses a sphere of large radius, its tangent plane turns more slowly in space than the tangent plane to a sphere of smaller radius: the sphere of radius R has curvature 1/R^2. Manifolds of curvature greater than or equal to zero have been an active area of study for many years, with most known examples produced by imposing some amount of symmetry, with the sphere and its large group of rotations being the most symmetric example.

These research projects bring homotopy-theoretic tools into the approach of Grove and Ziller to the study of Riemannian manifolds of non-negative curvature. Some of the questions to be studied follow on well-known theorems and conjectures of Adem, Adams, and Chern. In particular, a generalization is suggested of Adams' theorem on singly-generated cohomology rings and generalizations in the presence of symmetry for Chern's problem on the fundamental groups of positively curved manifolds are considered.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant provided the PI with an excellent opportunity to better establish his new and growing research program, to sustain existing collaborations and begin new ones, and to support his efforts to mentor a talented, hard working, and diverse groups of undergraduate and graduate students. 

Regarding his research program, the PI was very pleased to solve one of the major problems he outlined in the project's proposal submitted in Fall 2013. The achievement was made in joint efforts with collaborators (Manuel Amann and later Burkhard Wilking), and the funding from this grant and other NSF sources (especially by way of MSRI) was crucial. Without multiple opportunities to visit each other, initial and continuing conversations about the problem would not have been had, and the problem would very likely remain open today. 

In addition to these collaborations, the PI was able to use funds from this grant to support the initiation of new collaborations with mathematicians from across the country, Germany, and China. Such research networks are critical to the communication of results and to the production of new ones. Two of these collaborations directly led to the formulation of a new direction in the PI's research program, something that the PI and his collaborators intend to develop in the coming years.

Finally, the PI is proud of his time spent mentoring students at the undergraduate and graduate level. He strives to improve their critical thinking, research practices, and writing ability. These skills are important both for budding mathematicians and for the growing percentage of those who move on to careers outside of academic mathematical research careers.
